Description: Moderne style electric guitar - Glen Miller Version The Gibson Moderne is the missing link in the late 1950’s Gibson “Modernistic Guitars” series that failed spectacularly when released and then went on to define the look of so many electric guitars of the future. The Explorer and the Flying V were produced and sold in small numbers - until “rediscovered” in the late 60’s - but the “Moderne” was never released back in the day. In that respect, their is no truly “original” Moderne, just the many homages to it’s unique sweeping design including, of course, the Gibson and Epiphone “re-releases” starting in the 1980’s. This guitar is one of the versions created by luthier Glen Miller of Wrona’s House of Violins in upstate New York. The story goes that they had purchased old stock from the Gibson factory in Kalamazoo, MI and created a series of instruments with those authentic materials. This is one of those guitars. The Moderne is the kind of instrument one either loves or hates. Full disclosure - I love them. In fact, the only thing I never loved about the Moderne was the original headstock design, a large fanned out piece of wood usually referred to as the “Gumby” headstock. Imagine my delight 10 years ago when I saw this very guitar sporting Mr. Miller’s ingenious mash up that put the split V shaped headstock known as the “Futura” style on this Moderne. It’s a look Gibson later included in a 2012 release so I imagine it’s a popular one. Made of mahogany and fitted with Bill Lawrence humbuckers, this guitar features a substantial neck (I believe ebony - possibly dark rosewood) and is a dream to play. The details of the Moderne story are enough to write a book about and fortunately such a book has been written. Among other treats about this mysterious artifact of the history of the electric guitar, it also happens to include a short section on Glen Miller’s creations and images of this very instrument. It didn’t seem right to let someone have this guitar without a copy of the book so I’m including one along with the original bill of sale. FYI - depending of the light, the guitar can photograph towards either brown or cherry. There are two issues to be mentioned. The case is more of a “shipping” case than a “gigging” case. It’s a Gibson case and fits the Moderne’s shape perfectly but the latches, while workable, are fragile. The other is the fact that one end of the gold plastic “Gibson” logo on the headstock isn’t fully adhered to the headstock. Meaning it should be secured at some point. I don’t do things like that so I haven’t touched it. Finally, I am leaving my Dunlop strap locks on the guitar and including the leather strap I used with it.
Title: Moderne style electric guitar- Glen Miller Version
